factoid: The instructions to Alpátych took over two hours.
The prince did not let Alpátych go.
The prince sat down.
The prince sank into thought.
The prince closed his eyes.
The prince dozed off.
Alpátych made a slight movement.
The prince told Alpátych to go.
Alpátych went out.
The prince went to his bureau.
The prince glanced into his bureau.
The prince fingered his papers.
The prince closed the bureau.
The prince sat down at the table.
The prince wrote to the governor.
It was already late when the prince rose after sealing the letter.
The prince wished to sleep.
The prince knew he would not be able to sleep.
The prince knew that most depressing thoughts came to him in bed.
The prince called Tíkhon.
The prince went through the rooms with Tíkhon.
The prince showed Tíkhon where to set up the bed for that night.
The prince looked at every corner.
Every place seemed unsatisfactory to the prince.
The prince's customary couch in the study was the worst.
The couch was dreadful to the prince.
The couch was probably dreadful because of the oppressive thoughts the prince had had when lying there.
The corner behind the piano in the sitting room was better than other places.
The prince had never slept there yet.
Tíkhon, with the help of a footman, brought in the bedstead.
Tíkhon began putting the bedstead up.
The prince cried, "That's not right! That's not right!".
The prince pushed the bedstead a few inches from the corner.
The prince pushed the bedstead closer in again.
The prince thought, "Well, at last I've finished, now I'll rest.".
The prince let Tíkhon undress him.
The prince frowning with vexation at the effort necessary to divest himself of his coat and trousers.
The prince undressed.
The prince sat down heavily on the bed.
The prince appeared to be meditating while looking contemptuously at his withered yellow legs.
The prince was not meditating.
The prince was deferring the moment of making the effort to lift his legs up and turn over on the bed.
The prince thought, "Ugh, how hard it is! Oh, that this toil might end and you would release me!".
The prince pressed his lips together.
The prince made that effort for the twenty-thousandth time.
The prince lay down.
The prince felt the bed rocking backwards and forwards beneath him as if it were breathing heavily and jolting.
The bed rocking happened to the prince almost every night.
The prince opened his eyes as they were closing.
The prince muttered, "No peace, damn them!".
The prince was angry, but did not know with whom.
The prince said, "Ah yes, there was something else important, very important, that I was keeping till I should be in bed.".
The prince was keeping something important in his pocket until he should be in bed.
The prince said, "The bolts? No, I told him about them.".
The prince said, "No, it was something, something in the drawing room.".
Princess Mary talked some nonsense.
Dessalles, that fool, said something.
The prince said, "Something in my pocket—can’t remember...".
The prince asked Tíkhon, "What did we talk about at dinner?".
Tíkhon answered, "About Prince Michael...".
The prince slapped his hand on the table.
The prince said, "Be quiet, quiet!".
The prince said, "Yes, I know, Prince Andrew's letter!".
The prince said, "Princess Mary read it.".
The prince said, "Dessalles said something about Vítebsk.".
The prince said, "Now I'll read it.".
The prince had the letter taken from his pocket.
The table had a glass of lemonade and a spiral wax candle on it.
The prince moved the table close to the bed.
The prince put on his spectacles.
The prince began reading.
The prince grasped the meaning of the letter for a moment while reading it by the faint light under the green shade at night.
The prince read that the French at Vítebsk may be at Smolénsk in four days' march.
The prince thought, "Perhaps they are already there!".
Tíkhon jumped up.
Tíkhon shouted, "No, no, I don't want anything!".
The prince put the letter under the candlestick.
The prince closed his eyes.
The prince had a vision of the Danube at bright noonday.
The vision included reeds.
The vision included a Russian camp.
In the vision, the prince saw himself as a young general without a wrinkle on his ruddy face, vigorous and alert, entering Potëmkin's gaily colored tent.
In the vision, a burning sense of jealousy of "the favorite" agitated the prince as strongly as it had done then.
The prince recalled all the words spoken at the first meeting with Potëmkin.
The prince saw a plump, rather sallow-faced, short, stout woman, the Empress Mother, with her smile and her words at her first gracious reception of him.
The prince saw that same face on the catafalque.
The prince recalled the encounter he had with Zúbov over her coffin about his right to kiss her hand.
